prompt: Facts: Petitioners (Rishi Anand and Pranav Ansal) were Directors of M/s. Green Park Theatres Associated Pvt. Ltd., which owned and ran Uphaar Cinema in Green Park, New Delhi.; On 13th June 1997, during the 3:00 PM matinee show of the movie 'Border', a major fire broke out originating from a transformer in the ground floor parking area.; The fire and subsequent smoke resulted in the deaths of 59 patrons and injuries to over 100 others, primarily due to asphyxiation and stampede.; An FIR No. 432/97 was registered at Police Station Hauz Khas, New Delhi.; Investigation revealed alleged gross negligence and violations of safety norms, including installation of extra seats in the balcony which allegedly blocked one of the exit gangways.; The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) took over the investigation.; The Trial Court framed charges against the petitioners and other accused under Sections 304-A, 337, 338 read with Section 34 IPC, and Section 14 of the Cinematograph Act, 1952.; The specific allegation against the petitioners (Directors) was their role in the management and control of the cinema hall, implying knowledge and responsibility for the unsafe conditions, particularly the unauthorized extra seats blocking the exit.; The petitioners filed a petition before the High Court of Delhi under Section 482 CrPC seeking quashing of the charges, which was dismissed.; The petitioners then approached the Supreme Court via a Special Leave Petition challenging the High Court's refusal to quash the charges.; The Supreme Court heard the appeal against the order refusing to quash the charges framed by the Trial Court. | IPC: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention), Section 304-A (Causing death by negligence), Section 337 (Causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others), Section 338 (Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others), Section 304 Part II (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Mentioned contextually but not charged by trial court against these petitioners at this stage)
